issue.title: Arduino says sketch should be in subdirectory called ProffieOS, which it already is.

labels.name: status: waiting for information
labels.description: More information must be provided before work can proceed

labels.name: type: imperfection
labels.description: Perceived defect in any part of project

issue.body:
### Describe the problem

I have a file called "ProffieOS.ino". It is in a directory called "ProffieOS".
I run the arduno 2.2.1 app image and regardless of how I try to open this ino file, it complains that it needs to be in a subdirectory called "ProffieOS", then offers to move the file, which would mess up all my include paths.

It seems unlikely that this would happen to everybody all the time, but I haven't found an easy way to figure out *why* Arduino thinks that my ProffieOS folder isn't named ProffieOS.

I think there must be a file inside my ProffieOS directory which is confusing Arduino, because when I download a fresh copy of ProffieOS Arduino seems to open it just fine. However, if that is the case, then Arduino should just say so.


### To reproduce

arduino-ide_2.2.1_LInux_64bit.AppImage ProffieOS/ProffieOS.ino


### Expected behavior

Arduino should recognize that the sketch is already in a directory with the right name.

### Arduino IDE version

2.2.1

### Operating system

Linux

### Operating system version

Ubuntu 20.05.5 LTS

### Additional context

The full path name for my ProffieOS folder is /net/cytocin/home/hubbe/hack/teensy/lightsaber/ProffieOS


### Issue checklist

- [X] I searched for previous reports in [the issue tracker](https://github.com/arduino/arduino-ide/issues?q=)
- [X] I verified the problem still occurs when using the latest [nightly build](https://www.arduino.cc/en/software#nightly-builds)
- [X] My report contains all necessary details

comment.body:
The problem seems to be a file called ProffieOS/blades/.#pwm_pin.h
When I remove that file, Arduino is able to open the sketch.
This file is created by emacs while editing a file, and can sometimes be left behind.
Not sure why Arduino thinks that "ProffieOS" isn't called "ProffieOS" because it contains a .# file though...

comment.body:
These are the files/folders under the ProffieOS directory with the problem:

blades/
borked-color
buttons/
common/
config/
display/
doc/
elf.cc~
fontconvert/
functions/
ir/
libs/
LICENCE.txt
Makefile
motion/
mtp/
pov_tools/
pqoi/
ProffieOS.ino
props/
README.md
scripts/
show_notworking
show_working
sound/
styles/
transitions/
v6_announce.txt
v6_announce.txt~
v7.x-diff
videotoblc/
zipfiles/

None of these seems to have "meaningful" names to me.
I suppose arduino might be looking in subdirectories for something?

comment.body:
/net/ is in fact a normal directory in this case, it's not a magic NFS mount or anything.
All my files are under /net/, including the directory where I downloaded, unzipped and tested the plain copy of ProffieOS.

comment.body:
Hi @profezzorn. Thanks for your report.

I note the `/net/` in the path. Does the fault still occur if you move the bad copy of the sketch to a location that is not under `/net/`? When you downloaded the fresh copy of the sketch that did not produce the fault, was its path under `/net/`?

issue.title: chore(deps): update to Theia `1.42.1`

labels.name: type: enhancement
labels.description: Proposed improvement

labels.name: topic: theia
labels.description: Related to the Theia IDE framework

issue.body:
## ~Depends on https://github.com/arduino/arduino-ide/pull/2252~ ✅ 

### Motivation

Use the latest Theia version: `1.42.1`.

<!-- Why this pull request? -->

### Change description
 - Update VS Code translation versions to `1.81.0` (where available)
 - Disable eclipse-theia/theia#12867

<!-- What does your code do? -->

### Other information

<!-- Any additional information that could help the review process -->

IDE2 will automatically get the multi-line search feature from Theia (eclipse-theia/theia#12868):


https://github.com/arduino/arduino-ide/assets/1405703/d3073b0c-fd8f-4add-b5d1-80c2c76076b7


I do not expect any other Theia behavioral changes, but here is the diff: https://github.com/eclipse-theia/theia/compare/v1.41.0...v1.42.1. I disabled one undesired new feature (eclipse-theia/theia#12867) from Theia.

### Reviewer checklist

- [ ] PR addresses a single concern.
- [ ] The PR has no duplicates (please search among the [Pull Requests](https://github.com/arduino/arduino-ide/pulls) before creating one)
- [ ] PR title and description are properly filled.
- [ ] Docs have been added / updated (for bug fixes / features)

issue.title: Serial monitor copy not functional on MacOS

labels.name: type: imperfection
labels.description: Perceived defect in any part of project

labels.name: topic: serial monitor
labels.description: Related to the Serial Monitor

issue.body:
### Describe the problem

Create a sketch, compile, upload, view Serial Monitor, click anywhere in the Serial Monitor panel, get no response. I am hunting for a way to copy text. For example, I compile, upload, and run a new sketch and see this in the Serial Monitor panel:

```
Info, Reflections of Frank
Starting new log file, forcecount = 0
Opened log file /log333, mylog.size() = 41
Info, Host: REFLECTIONS-88
Info, mjpegFile = /a130f0c903a0472cd043cd2252a5f3a4/a130f0c903a0472cd043cd2252a5f3a4.mjpeg
Guru Meditation Error: Core  1 panic’ed (LoadProhibited). Exception was unhandled.

Core  1 register dump:
PC      : 0x420e6c31  PS      : 0x00060b30  A0      : 0x820079b9  A1      : 0x3fcebf20  
A2      : 0x3fca2770  A3      : 0xb5ac8f7d  A4      : 0xb5ac8f7d  A5      : 0x3fca51e0  
A6      : 0x3fca2e70  A7      : 0xff000000  A8      : 0x82007896  A9      : 0x3fcebed0  
A10     : 0x00000000  A11     : 0x0011e37f  A12     : 0x00000000  A13     : 0x00000000  
A14     : 0x3fca51e0  A15     : 0x00000001  SAR     : 0x0000000a  EXCCAUSE: 0x0000001c  
EXCVADDR: 0x00000000  LBEG    : 0x40056f5c  LEND    : 0x40056f72  LCOUNT  : 0xffffffff  


Backtrace: 0x420e6c2e:0x3fcebf20 0x420079b6:0x3fcebf40 0x42007e5f:0x3fcebf60 0x42047f52:0x3fcebfd0
```
I roll the mouse over the above Backtrace text. Click and drag or right double click. I get no activity. No text selection.





### To reproduce

Create a sketch
Enter source code
Compile and upload
View Serial Monitor
Click and drag within the service monitor.
No selection made.

### Expected behavior

Highlighted selected text appears within the Serial Monitor panel.

### Arduino IDE version

arduino-ide_nightly-20231025_macOS_64bit

### Operating system

macOS

### Operating system version

Sonoma 14.0 (23A344)

### Additional context

Same behavior in:
arduino-ide_nightly-20230804_macOS_64bit
and Arduino IDE 2.2.1


### Issue checklist

- [X] I searched for previous reports in [the issue tracker](https://github.com/arduino/arduino-ide/issues?q=)
- [X] I verified the problem still occurs when using the latest [nightly build](https://www.arduino.cc/en/software#nightly-builds)
- [X] My report contains all necessary details

comment.body:
Thanks! That screencast was very valuable. I see now that this is a bug in the "Light High Contrast" theme you are using:

![sm-highlight](https://github.com/arduino/arduino-ide/assets/8572152/4ece83e1-b646-4e58-a48f-5d3798e7aa45)

Notice that when any of the other themes are selected, the highlight is visible.

The low level functionality of the highlight works fine even though it is not visible. You can copy the invisibly highlighted text to the clipboard as usual.

comment.body:
Thank you for the reply and video. Here is what I am seeing... 

https://github.com/arduino/arduino-ide/assets/6834993/92d92a40-bcf6-4870-9261-21fe2aba57e1

I get the same behavior using Night Builds: October 25, 2023 and August 15, 2023.

I don't think it's a hardware issue, yet I should tell you this is on my open-source Reflections dev board, using ESP32-S3 and JTAG over USB
https://github.com/frankcohen/ReflectionsOS/blob/main/Docs/images/CindyLou.jpg

Here are the board settings in Arduino IDE 2.2.1:
https://github.com/frankcohen/ReflectionsOS/blob/main/Docs/images/ESP32-S3_Board_Settings.jpg

I'm glad to help in any way.

-Frank

issue.title: Add extension manager interface

labels.name: type: enhancement
labels.description: Proposed improvement

labels.name: conclusion: declined
labels.description: Will not be worked on

labels.name: topic: code
labels.description: Related to content of the project itself

issue.body:
I think that, being based on Theia, this IDE should be compatible more or less out of the box with the open vsx ecosystem, right?

https://www.gitpod.io/blog/open-vsx/

Can we get a dedicated menu / pane to the Debug / Boards Manager / Library Manager ones, but dedicated to user installed plugins and extensions, to be able to install such extensions and plugins manually?

comment.body:
Hi @FlightControl-User. Thanks for your interest in Arduino IDE extensions! This issue tracker is only to be used to report bugs or feature requests specific to the project, and to discussions tightly focused on the implementation of the fixes and features in the codebase. Assistance with making 3rd party extensions is more appropriate for the Arduino Forum. I'm sure we will be able to help you out over there:

https://forum.arduino.cc/c/software/ide-2-x/93

comment.body:
Thanks for your report @frankcohen. I tried it on my macOS Sonoma machine and found that highlighting by doing a click and drag in the Serial Monitor view works as expected:

![sm-select](https://github.com/arduino/arduino-ide/assets/8572152/61c24805-e27f-404c-a090-f5d9cfd8bf99)

Please try to replicate the click and drag action shown in my screencast above and then comment here to tell us whether the Serial Monitor content is highlighted.

There are some known bugs related to highlighting text in Serial Monitor:

- https://github.com/arduino/arduino-ide/issues/247
- https://github.com/arduino/arduino-ide/issues/1081

However, neither of those seem to me to match the behavior you describe.

issue.title: Serial data reception drops characters causing unreliable data communication

labels.name: type: imperfection
labels.description: Perceived defect in any part of project

issue.body:
### Describe the problem

I'm not sure if this is the correct place for this issue. The issue is not a direct IDE related issue, it's about the Arduino platform.

Marlin uses the Arduino framework to received serial data with the support of interrupts.
After enabling CRC codes for the Gcodes I send to Marlin, and stressing Marlin (sending more commands) I found that some serial characters are lost once in a while. Adding some debug code did not resolve the issue, the provided uart error code was 0, also no error flags were set (NE, FE, PE).

### To reproduce

Send serial data to the Arduino serial port at a high rate, speed 250K baud or above. (Faster rates cause more problems)
Command length: >35 characters
Command rate > 120 commands per second (faster rates cause more problems)
Check if the commands are received correctly.
I never saw any data corruption, the problem is always that a character is not received.
At 115200 baud the problem is less frequent, but still occurs.

I found that reading the serial data with DMA solves the problem completely!

### Expected behavior

Receive the data correctly, no missing characters.

### Arduino IDE version

2.2.1

### Operating system

Windows

### Operating system version

Windows 10 Enterprise

### Additional context

Hardware used for receiving the data: STM32F407 (MKS Monster 8 V1.0) running Marlin.
Hardware used for sending the data: BTT TFT35 V3.0 (STM32F207)

I monitored the data received by the STM32F407 with an additional serial port I put in parallel to the STM32F407 board. There I can see that there is no data corruption and no data loss. The data is send correctly, but not processed correctly by the STM32F407.

**Additionally I programmed an experimental DMA reading algorithm to check if this is more reliable. This proved to be a great solution, and allows for serial rates of 1M baud without having this issue. This makes me think the problem is located in the Arduino platform.**

### Issue checklist

- [X] I searched for previous reports in [the issue tracker](https://github.com/arduino/arduino-ide/issues?q=)

issue.title: Serial data reception drops characters causing unreliable data communication

labels.name: type: imperfection
labels.description: Perceived defect in any part of project

issue.body:
### Describe the problem

I'm not sure if this is the correct place for this issue. The issue is not a direct IDE related issue, it's about the Arduino platform.

Marlin uses the Arduino framework to received serial data with the support of interrupts.
After enabling CRC codes for the Gcodes I send to Marlin, and stressing Marlin (sending more commands) I found that some serial characters are lost once in a while. Adding some debug code did not resolve the issue, the provided uart error code was 0, also no error flags were set (NE, FE, PE).

### To reproduce

Send serial data to the Arduino serial port at a high rate, speed 250K baud or above. (Faster rates cause more problems)
Command length: >35 characters
Command rate > 120 commands per second (faster rates cause more problems)
Check if the commands are received correctly.
I never saw any data corruption, the problem is always that a character is not received.
At 115200 baud the problem is less frequent, but still occurs.

I found that reading the serial data with DMA solves the problem completely!

### Expected behavior

Receive the data correctly, no missing characters.

### Arduino IDE version

2.2.1

### Operating system

Windows

### Operating system version

Windows 10 Enterprise

### Additional context

Hardware used for receiving the data: STM32F407 (MKS Monster 8 V1.0) running Marlin.
Hardware used for sending the data: BTT TFT35 V3.0 (STM32F207)

I monitored the data received by the STM32F407 with an additional serial port I put in parallel to the STM32F407 board. There I can see that there is no data corruption and no data loss. The data is send correctly, but not processed correctly by the STM32F407.

**Additionally I programmed an experimental DMA reading algorithm to check if this is more reliable. This proved to be a great solution, and allows for serial rates of 1M baud without having this issue. This makes me think the problem is located in the Arduino platform.**

### Issue checklist

- [X] I searched for previous reports in [the issue tracker](https://github.com/arduino/arduino-ide/issues?q=)
- [X] I verified the problem still occurs when using the latest [nightly build](https://www.arduino.cc/en/software#nightly-builds)
- [X] My report contains all necessary details

comment.body:
Hi @rondlh. Thanks for your interest in this free open source software project.

>reading the serial data with DMA solves the problem completely!

This issue tracker is only used for tracking bug reports and feature requests directly related to the Arduino IDE application code hosted in this repository. As you explained, your excellent investigation shows that the fault is not in the Arduino IDE codebase. You should report the problem to the developers of the software where the bug/deficiency is located.

issue.title: Serial monitor copy not functional on MacOS

labels.name: type: imperfection
labels.description: Perceived defect in any part of project

issue.body:
### Describe the problem

Create a sketch, compile, upload, view Serial Monitor, click anywhere in the Serial Monitor panel, get no response. I am hunting for a way to copy text. For example, I compile, upload, and run a new sketch and see this in the Serial Monitor panel:

```
Info, Reflections of Frank
Starting new log file, forcecount = 0
Opened log file /log333, mylog.size() = 41
Info, Host: REFLECTIONS-88
Info, mjpegFile = /a130f0c903a0472cd043cd2252a5f3a4/a130f0c903a0472cd043cd2252a5f3a4.mjpeg
Guru Meditation Error: Core  1 panic’ed (LoadProhibited). Exception was unhandled.

Core  1 register dump:
PC      : 0x420e6c31  PS      : 0x00060b30  A0      : 0x820079b9  A1      : 0x3fcebf20  
A2      : 0x3fca2770  A3      : 0xb5ac8f7d  A4      : 0xb5ac8f7d  A5      : 0x3fca51e0  
A6      : 0x3fca2e70  A7      : 0xff000000  A8      : 0x82007896  A9      : 0x3fcebed0  
A10     : 0x00000000  A11     : 0x0011e37f  A12     : 0x00000000  A13     : 0x00000000  
A14     : 0x3fca51e0  A15     : 0x00000001  SAR     : 0x0000000a  EXCCAUSE: 0x0000001c  
EXCVADDR: 0x00000000  LBEG    : 0x40056f5c  LEND    : 0x40056f72  LCOUNT  : 0xffffffff  


Backtrace: 0x420e6c2e:0x3fcebf20 0x420079b6:0x3fcebf40 0x42007e5f:0x3fcebf60 0x42047f52:0x3fcebfd0
```
I roll the mouse over the above Backtrace text. Click and drag or right double click. I get no activity. No text selection.





### To reproduce

Create a sketch
Enter source code
Compile and upload
View Serial Monitor
Click and drag within the service monitor.
No selection made.

### Expected behavior

Highlighted selected text appears within the Serial Monitor panel.

### Arduino IDE version

arduino-ide_nightly-20231025_macOS_64bit

### Operating system

macOS

### Operating system version

Sonoma 14.0 (23A344)

### Additional context

Same behavior in:
arduino-ide_nightly-20230804_macOS_64bit
and Arduino IDE 2.2.1


### Issue checklist

- [X] I searched for previous reports in [the issue tracker](https://github.com/arduino/arduino-ide/issues?q=)

- [X] My report contains all necessary details

review.body:
## Compile operations can't be triggered

### Describe the problem

Triggering any of the following operations has no effect:

- Verify/Compile
- Upload
- Upload Using Programmer
- Export Compiled Binary

### To reproduce

1. Select any board from the **Tools > Board** menu.
1. Select **Sketch > Verify/Compile** from the Arduino IDE menus.

🐛 There is no reaction.

### Arduino IDE version

133ff30 (tester build for 46632076e952dc9c76d05e11b515834dcbfb8d2e)

### Operating system

Windows 11

### Additional context

The fault is not present when using the latest build from the `main` branch (69b7365)

---

Triggering the fault doesn't cause any log output to be produced.

---

The fault occurs regardless of how the operation is triggered:

- Via the menu items
- Via the toolbar buttons
- Via the command palette

---

Other operations such as **Tools > Burn Bootloader**, Library Manager installation, Boards Manager installation do work as expected.

issue.title: Make board serial number text copyable in "Board Info" dialog

labels.name: type: enhancement
labels.description: Proposed improvement

labels.name: topic: code
labels.description: Related to content of the project itself

issue.body:
### Describe the request

Allow the user to select the text in the "**Board Info**" dialog, or copy it to the clipboard by some other mechanism.

🙂 This will make it easy for the user to obtain the text of the board's serial number.

### Describe the current behavior

When the user selects **Tools > Board Info** from the Arduino IDE menus, a dialog opens that shows information about the selected port:

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/8572152/220217049-cf22a959-dab5-4c4d-b4a0-4f04a5fe71d2.png)

This information includes the board serial number, which might be requested by Arduino technical support or required for the registration of associated software products such as:

- [**Lauterbach TRACE32 Debugger**](https://docs.arduino.cc/tutorials/portenta-h7/lauterbach-debugger#2-registration-and-license-key)
- [**Arduino Speech Recognition Engine**](https://store-usa.arduino.cc/products/speech-recognition-engine)

The serial number may be dozens of characters long. The text in the "**Board Info**" dialog is not selectable and no mechanism is available for copying it.

🙁 Manually transcribing the serial number from the dialog is inconvenient and error prone.

### Arduino IDE version

d68bc4a

### Operating system

Windows

### Operating system version

11

### Additional context

The text in the dialog is selectable in Arduino IDE 1.x

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/8572152/220217224-f26b0fbe-0dfb-435e-9cb2-d5d852f4e135.png)

### Issue checklist

- [X] I searched for previous requests in [the issue tracker](https://github.com/arduino/arduino-ide/issues?q=)
- [X] I verified the feature was still missing when using the latest [nightly build](https://www.arduino.cc/en/software#nightly-builds)
- [X] My request contains all necessary details

comment.body:
Ctrl+C when the dialog box is in focus will copy the details. You can paste it to the Notepad and get the appropriate details. Screenshot shown below

![image](https://github.com/arduino/arduino-ide/assets/5036103/ba724f99-df5c-4706-9407-a68c5371cb71)

Tested with Arduino 2.2.2 on Windows 11

issue.title: Port left open after closing Serial Plotter

labels.name: topic: code
labels.description: Related to content of the project itself

labels.name: type: imperfection
labels.description: Perceived defect in any part of project

labels.name: criticality: medium
labels.description: Of moderate impact

issue.body:
### Describe the problem

If one process has a serial port open, another can not access it. Arduino IDE is designed to automatically manage access to ports by the various operations and components that use them:

- Uploading sketches
- Serial Monitor
- Serial Plotter
- Updating radio module firmware
- Uploading SSL certificates to radio module

The user may also use the port from an external application during sketch development in Arduino IDE. They will be responsible for managing the access of the port by the IDE and the external application. This means that the IDE must always relinquish port access when the user closes a component using the port

🐛 The port is left open after closing the Serial Plotter window.

### To reproduce

1. Select a serial port in the Arduino IDE.
1. Select **Tools > Serial Plotter** from the Arduino IDE menus to open the "**Serial Plotter**".
1. Close the "**Serial Plotter**" window.
1. Open the port in an external application.

🐛 Opening the port fails.

### Expected behavior

Port is closed when Serial Plotter window is closed.

### Arduino IDE version

2.0.0-rc9.4

### Operating system

Windows, Linux

### Operating system version

Windows 10, Ubuntu 20.04

### Additional context

From Windows Task Manager and GNOME System Monitor, I can see that the [serial-monitor](https://github.com/arduino/serial-monitor) process is not being closed when the Serial Plotter window is closed.

---

I bisected the introduction of the issue to df8658e

---

The problem does not occur if the procedure described above is performed using Serial Monitor instead of Serial Plotter (in fact cycling Serial Monitor open and then closed again closes the port after it was left open by Serial Plotter).

---

The issue does not occur when using Arduino IDE 1.8.19 Serial Monitor

---

Some options for external applications that can be used for the final step in the demo:

- Arduino CLI
- Arduino IDE 1.x
- [PuTTY / Plink](https://www.chiark.greenend.org.uk/~sgtatham/putty/)
- [`screen`](https://www.gnu.org/software/screen/manual/screen.html)
- [Realterm](https://realterm.sourceforge.io/)

```text
$ arduino-cli upload --fqbn arduino:avr:uno --port COM7
avrdude: ser_open(): can't open device "\\.\COM7": Access is denied.
```

```text
$ arduino-cli upload --fqbn arduino:samd:mkrzero --port COM47
TOUCH: error during reset: opening port at 1200bps: Serial port busy
No device found on COM47
Error during Upload: Failed uploading: uploading error: exit status 1
```

```text
$ arduino-cli monitor --port COM7
Port monitor error: command 'open' failed: Serial port busy
```

Opening the port in Arduino IDE 1.x Serial Monitor

```text
Error opening serial port 'COM7'. (Port busy)
```

### Issue checklist

- [X] I searched for previous reports in [the issue tracker](https://github.com/arduino/arduino-ide/issues?q=)
- [X] I verified the problem still occurs when using the latest [nightly build](https://github.com/arduino/arduino-ide#nightly-builds)
- [X] My report contains all necessary details

comment.body: @per1234 I just noticed this issue with the 2.x IDE I have installed. Using the Serial Plotter always leaves the serial port busy, no matter how I close the Plotter. If I then start/stop the Serial Monitor in the IDE, the port is released.

issue.title: Ping Timeout error while compiling

labels.name: topic: code
labels.description: Related to content of the project itself

labels.name: type: imperfection
labels.description: Perceived defect in any part of project

issue.body:
### Describe the problem

I am seeing random "ping timeout" errors while compiling with the latest update.

Not really sure what it could be pinging i do not have any internet related functions, all the files are local. 

### To reproduce

Issue Verify or Upload command

### Expected behavior

Compile to complete or error message

### Arduino IDE version

2.2.1

### Operating system

Windows

### Operating system version

10

### Additional context

I have also seen random issues with the com port not being recognized, when it does this the "board" section in the menu is missing.

There are also times when the compile never completes as well and it requires a shutdown and restart. The arrow remains greyed out, but the compile complete message never happens.

#### Additional reports

- https://github.com/arduino/arduino-ide/issues/2218#issuecomment-1711896048
- https://github.com/arduino/arduino-ide/issues/2218#issuecomment-1712391001
- https://github.com/arduino/arduino-ide/issues/2218#issuecomment-1738614255
- https://forum.arduino.cc/t/arduino-2-2-1-reports-ping-timeout/1171773
- https://forum.arduino.cc/t/compile-fails-with-esp32s-weird-message-ping-timeout/1172837

### Issue checklist

- [X] I searched for previous reports in [the issue tracker](https://github.com/arduino/arduino-ide/issues?q=)
- [X] I verified the problem still occurs when using the latest [nightly build](https://www.arduino.cc/en/software#nightly-builds)
- [X] My report contains all necessary details

comment.body:
Same problem with esp32 boards like ESP32C3, ESP32S3 and ESP32 RRGO T-watch. 
in The folder c:\Users\ednie\AppData\Local\Temp\  one can find the temporary sketch precompile data
When comparing it with a sketch from the IDE1.8.19 I see a part of the files the IDE2.2.1 stores are stored in another folder named: c:\Users\ednie\AppData\Local\Temp\arduino\sketches\

 The "ping timeout" occurs when the line: 
Using library EEPROM at version 2.0.0 in folder: :\Users\ednie\AppData\Local\Arduino15\packages\esp32\hardware\esp32\2.0.14\libraries\EEPROM 
is written.

in the Arduino 1.8.19 the last lines are:

Using library EEPROM at version 2.0.0 in folder: C:\Users\ednie\AppData\Local\Arduino15\packages\esp32\hardware\esp32\2.0.14\libraries\EEPROM 
"C:\\Users\\ednie\\AppData\\Local\\Arduino15\\packages\\esp32\\tools\\xtensa-esp32-elf-gcc\\esp-2021r2-patch5-8.4.0/bin/xtensa-esp32-elf-size" -A "C:\\Users\\ednie\\AppData\\Local\\Temp\\arduino_build_955993/TTGO-wordClock-V001.ino.elf"
Sketch uses 438129 bytes (6%) of program storage space. Maximum is 6553600 bytes.
Global variables use 24296 bytes (0%) of dynamic memory, leaving 4497688 bytes for local variables. Maximum is 4521984 bytes.

It look like that "xtensa-esp32-elf-size.exe" is not executed properly. 
Maybe part on the necessary files are stored in the wrong folder?

Before the ping out problem  I had the compiler error comment: before after compiling : "connection got disposed"
See #1587
